bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, June 3, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas describes cases of yellow fever in the Canal Zone, and the reaction to the new Sanitary Commission.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, June 3, 1905
div1.opener:
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, CANAL ZONE.
June 3, 1905.
Gen. Robert M. O'Rielly,
Surgeon-General, U.S.A.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear General:-
div1.p:
I enclose you correspondence with regard to LaGarde and
Phillips. I cabled you yesterday, as Ireland directed, the fact that Phillips
has been asked for.

The new Commission has given a considerable impetus to work generally,
and everybody feels pretty well stirred up, and each man is trying to put
his best foot foremost; the Sanitary Department with the others.

As you see by our daily reports, yellow fever continues to give us
trouble. The infecting of the Administration Building gave us a considerable
setback. It has apparently spread the infection around the town in various
directions when we had about gotten rid of it, but I hope soon to have it
scotched out again. The last death in the city of Panama occurred on the
28th of May and the last in Colon on the 15th of May; the cases since then
have been mild in type. At present we have only one serious case on hand;
but you will have seen Kean before you get this and he can tell you just
how things look down here.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, W.C. Gorgas
Chief Sanitary Officer.
